> From: Leonardo Abreu de Barros [mailto:leobarros@...]

> I have a s=
imple question about arranging related tests inside a test 
> case:
> 
> - =
Let`s say I have three tests that in some way depend on each other: 
> for =
example, a creation, a getter and a deletion method.
> These are distinct f=
unctionalities, and thus deserve to be on 
> separate tests. The problem is=
: if one fails, the other two will run 
> anyway. But if the creation or ge=
tter methods fail, it doesn`t make 
> sense for me to test the deletion met=
hod, as it depends on the 
> correctness of the other two. I know calling o=
ne test inside another 
> is not recommended. What should I do in this case=
? 

Put the assertions for all 3 responsibilities in one test method.  If t=
he first one fails, the whole method fails.  Call it testCRUD().

If you in=
sist on testing them as distinct functions in distinct tests, then duplicat=
e the test fixture for each one.  If they do not always fail together, then=
 this makes sense.

But if they are distinct, yet always fail together beca=
use they are interdependent, put them all in the same test method.
